newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila says "real" trade deficit not too bad.
newsitem.headline: Manila says "real" trade deficit not too bad.

text.p: The Philippine government said on Wednesday the country's widening trade deficit would not appear so high if foreign investment figures and earnings from overseas Filipino workers were taken into account.
The deficit in the country's trade and investments this year is expected to be less than $1 billion, Trade and Industry Secretary Cesar Bautista said in a statement.
"Many countries have already reported trade in terms of goods and services - such as the U.S., Britain, Singapore, Australia, Japan, Australia, etc.," he said.
The Central Bank recently said the country's merchandise trade deficit is expected to hit about $12.0 billion this year from $9.091 billion in 1995.
In the first eight months of this year, the trade deficit was $8.147 billion compared with $5.559 billion in the year-earlier period.
If portfolio and foreign direct investments are included, Bautista said "the 'real' gap in our trade/investments is less than $1 billion which is not a major worry."
